title: 103_hr3353
content: PART Q--JUVENILE DRUG TRAFFICKING AND GANG PREVENTION GRANTS. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include this new part, authorizing grants for juvenile drug trafficking and gang prevention. The Director is authorized to make grants to States and local governments for projects to reduce juvenile gang formation, drug use, and drug-related crimes. Grants can be used to reduce juvenile involvement in organized crime and drug-related crimes near schools. The Director is authorized to make grants to States and local governments for projects to reduce juvenile gang formation, drug use, and drug-related crimes. The grants aim to address juvenile involvement in organized crime, drug, and gang-related activities, provide counseling and treatment to offenders, and promote lawful activities for juveniles. The grants aim to reduce juvenile gang formation, drug use, and drug-related crimes by providing education, prevention, and treatment programs for juveniles involved in drug trafficking, drug use, or gang-related activities. This includes school programs, youth sports, scout troops, little leagues, and drug abuse treatment for pregnant juveniles and juvenile mothers. The grants aim to reduce juvenile gang formation, drug use, and drug-related crimes by providing education, prevention, and treatment programs for youth exposed to violence, establishing sports mentoring programs, addressing challenges faced by juveniles near International Ports of Entry, and identifying promising drug reduction programs. The federal grants aim to reduce juvenile gang formation, drug use, and drug-related crimes by providing education, prevention, and treatment programs for youth exposed to violence. The grants also focus on establishing sports mentoring programs and addressing challenges faced by juveniles near International Ports of Entry. Additionally, they aim to identify promising drug reduction programs and coordinate violence, gang, and juvenile drug prevention programs with other existing federal programs to better address the comprehensive needs of youth. The Federal share of a grant may not exceed 75 percent of the total costs of the projects described in applications submitted for the fiscal year. The Director may waive the 25 percent matching requirement under certain circumstances. The applicant's ability to meet requirements may be affected by financial circumstances. Applications for grants under this part must be submitted by a State or local government to the Director with the required information. The table of contents is amended to include a new section on Juvenile Drug Trafficking and Gang Prevention Grants. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations for projects under part Q of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include $100,000,000 for each of the fiscal years 1994 and 1995.
